name: NMDA Antagonists
summary: NMDA receptor antagonists modulate glutamatergic neurotransmission and have shown rapid-acting antidepressant effects, particularly in treatment-resistant depression. Ketamine and its derivative esketamine are the most studied agents.
description: NMDA antagonists act on the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor, a subtype of glutamate receptor critical in excitatory neurotransmission and synaptic plasticity. By modulating glutamate signaling, these drugs can induce rapid antidepressant effects, sometimes within hours. Ketamine, delivered intravenously, and intranasal esketamine are the leading examples, with FDA approval for treatment-resistant depression and depressive symptoms in major depressive disorder with acute suicidal ideation. Other NMDA antagonists, including investigational agents like rapastinel and apimostinel, are being studied to achieve similar efficacy with improved safety and tolerability.

metadata.equipment_required: Infusion equipment or intranasal delivery device, monitoring tools
metadata.training_required: Medical prescriber with training in ketamine/esketamine administration and monitoring
treatment_duration: Acute and maintenance protocols, often weeks to months
metadata.trial_phase: Phase II–III for novel agents; ketamine/esketamine FDA-approved for TRD
metadata.regulatory_status: FDA-approved for esketamine in TRD and depressive symptoms with suicidality; ketamine off-label use in psychiatry

clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Rapid symptom relief with transient dissociative, perceptual, and cardiovascular side effects. Long-term safety still under investigation.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong RCT evidence for ketamine and esketamine in TRD; mixed and emerging for novel NMDA modulators.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Extensive academic and industry research; NIH and pharmaceutical-sponsored trials ongoing.

items: Major depressive disorder with acute suicidality

sections.text: NMDA antagonists block NMDA receptors, reducing excessive glutamate activity and enhancing synaptic plasticity. Ketamine increases glutamate release and activates AMPA receptors, which may restore neural connectivity impaired in depression.

sections.preparation: Medical evaluation including psychiatric assessment, cardiovascular screening, and baseline labs.
procedure: IV ketamine: 0.5 mg/kg infused over 40 minutes in monitored setting.
Esketamine: intranasal dosing under supervision, with post-dose monitoring for 2 hours.
Investigational oral or subcutaneous agents administered in trials.
sections.frequency: Typically 2 sessions/week initially; taper to maintenance as indicated.
sections.duration: Acute course 4–6 weeks; maintenance may extend months to years.
sections.total_treatment_time: Variable depending on response and relapse prevention strategy.

special_considerations: Close monitoring required during and after administration

studies: Berman RM et al., 'Antidepressant effects of ketamine in depressed patients', Biol Psychiatry (2000).
Wilkinson ST et al., 'The effect of a single dose of intravenous ketamine on suicidal ideation', Depression & Anxiety (2018).
Daly EJ et al., 'Efficacy and safety of intranasal esketamine adjunctive to oral antidepressant therapy for treatment-resistant depression', JAMA Psychiatry (2019).
sections.limitations: Durability of effect remains limited; repeated dosing protocols and long-term outcomes require further study.

sections.typical_session_cost: $400–$800 per ketamine infusion; $600–$900 per esketamine session
sections.total_treatment_cost: Thousands of dollars per course; ongoing maintenance adds cost
sections.insurance_coverage: Esketamine covered by some insurers; ketamine typically out-of-pocket
sections.cost_effectiveness: Potentially cost-effective for rapid relief in severe TRD, but high cost limits accessibility

lifestyle_recommendations: Avoid driving or operating machinery same day

seo.title: NMDA Antagonists for Depression and Suicidality
seo.description: NMDA antagonists, including ketamine and esketamine, are rapid-acting antidepressants used in treatment-resistant depression and suicidality. Research continues into novel glutamate modulators.
